comment.author: 69758966@N08
comment._content: all are heroes and should never be forgotten our nation and our people owe a great deal to those who gave their lives so we could live in peace

comment.author: 29002582@N03
comment._content: www.flickr.com/photos/29002582@N03/5058050042/in/photostr... here is my grandad who fought in the battle of the somme. can this be added to this set?

comment.author: 69690351@N04
comment._content: www.flickr.com/photos/69690351@N04/ here is my Great Grandfather William Patrick Ryan, who served in the merchant navy in WW1 was sunk twice and survived. He also served in WW2, again in the Merchant navy but was sadly killed the first week of the war, as his ship the SS ORSA was hit by a torpedo coming out of port. With him in the photo is his brother Michael Leslie Ryan. who served in the 16th BN Highland light infantry. He was sadly killed in action on the first day of the Somme. Hope you can add there photo to your collection.

comment.author: 69692597@N02
comment._content: Total respect for these soldiers, real men, from a time when England was so great. God Bless them all, they died remembering a wonderful place, not the shambolic land we now live in.

comment.author: 16002177@N05
comment._content:
I have numerous photos of my grandpa & his brother who served in France during WW1.
My Grandpa thankfully made it back0minus his leg & most of his skull but his little brother was killed in 1916 leaving three little girls & an unborn son.

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/69690351@N04] Hi, thank you for your comment. We'd love you to add your Grandfather's portrait to a First World War Centenary project -- we'll be announcing something relevant over the coming months. Watch out for announcements on: Our website www.1914.org Our Facebook page Our Twitter account Thank you.

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: Thanks to everyone for your comments. If you have a spare minute, please light a light to help us remember those who died in the First World War, at www.1914.org/wall/

comment.author: 69733612@N03
comment._content: They are not just heros, they are our life. Maybe if we all did more to remember what it is was like, we would be more considerate to the mess we are making of the world today, for our children tomorrow.

comment.author: 32300107@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/69690351@N04] Since opening up Faces of the First World War we've had a number of requests from people like yourself wishing to share First World War portraits in their possession. We'd like to invite you to do so in our new group right here on Flickr, Your faces of the First World War many thanks.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: On checking FreeBMD birth records for K Nichol 1880-1903, only possible UK fit is NICHOL Kenneth birth reg 2nd qr 1901 Toxteth Park 8b 193 (Poss death date Nichol Kenneth age 32 1st qr 1934 W.Derby 8b 362 (also in Lancs), yet there is a Bedfordshire fire fighter Kenneth Nichol in 1941 - The National Archives. www.nationalarchives.gov.uk/a2a/records.aspx?cat=004-fs&a... If this was a British flyer, in 1918 he may have been an age to enter the rfc just before it became the RAF- is that not so? Then again he may not have been a UK flyer. Everyone seems to be drawing a blank on this first IWM posting.
